Syslinux can in no way directly chainloaded by grub4dos, see [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7013](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7013 "External link")  

Currently the only way to chainload syslinux from grub4dos is to write syslinux into a Volume Boot Record (use syslinux.exe d:, d: exchange with your letter) and to store that Volume Boot Record into a file (use hdhacker or similar tool). The file is not generic (each time you change partitions you need to create it again). But the file can be chainloaded by grub4dos with chainloader /syslinux.bin. Syslinux.bin will keep care to load ldlinux.sys then.  

> DOS (Floppy) - LinLd/GrUB4DOS - SysLinux (SD card)?

DOS (Floppy) -\> LinLd -\> SysLinux on USB cardreader: This can not work. LinLD can afaik only boot files in Linux kernel format. Syslinux is not in Linux kernel format and there is no Syslinux version in linux kernel format. EDIT: Even if syslinux would get somehow chainloaded from USB (supported by DOS USB driver) it would not work as syslinux is also using only the BIOS to access devices, DOS USB drivers are ignored.  

DOS (Floppy) + DOS USB drivers -\> GrUB4DOS -\> SysLinux on USB cardreader: This can not work. grub4dos will freeze DOS (with option to unfreeze) and use only the BIOS (which has no USB support) in order to chainload other devices, therefore grub4dos is not aware of the USB cardreader.  

If the USB cardreader is not seen by PLoP Bootmanager (this is the case here) you can only do it like:  
BIOS -\> floppy with DOS and DOS USB driver -\> LinLD -\> Linux kernel.

You can make a image file (**slax.img** ) which contains the kernel and initrd of slax and syslinux in the bootsector (+ needed menu files for syslinux) + menu.lst file + the squash file of slax.  

Make a kexec-loader config that boots grub4dos (you need grub.exe)  
I don't have time now to look how kexec-loader command works now, but it should be something like this:  

```
title slax

kernel (sdb1)/grub.exe

initrd (sdb1)/slax.img
```

This will boot the kernel version of grub4dos (grub.exe) and grub4dos will use slax.img as  
ramdisk image from which it can read the menu.lst file, the kernel and initrd.  

In the menu.lst file:  

```
title slax

chainloader +1
```

This will boot the syslinux bootloader. You need to install syslinux in the image file (slax.img) first of course.

@ Bicephale My approach described above with grub4dos should work. Probably it wasn't clear enough. * You have to make a disk image of 8 MB (slax.img) or larger (depends on the size of the /boot folder of slax). Make a hard disk image, install syslinux as bootloader on it. Copy the whole boot folder of slax to the hard disk image. * Put this hard disk image on your SD card (slax.img) * Put the /slax folder on your SD card. * Put grub.exe on your SD card. * Make the config file for kexec-loader: You can use the label name of your SD card to set the root device in kexec-loader (e.g. label 'SLAX'). ``` root LABEL=SLAX title Slax kernel /grub.exe --config-file="find --set-root /boot/slax.cfg; chainloader +1" initrd /slax.img ```
* This will first boot kexec-loader, which can see your SD card. * kexec-loader will find his config file on the SD card. * kexec-loader will then grab grub.exe and slax.img from the SD card. * kexec-loader will boot grub.exe with slax.img as ramdisk. * grub.exe will boot syslinux from the slax.img (which is in memory now, so grub.exe can access this image) by chainloading the first sector.
So you will still have the syslinux menu, from which you can choose the options that you like.

Install **syslinux** to it. * Compress this image with gzip so it will fit on a floppy (will be only a few kb in size now) (**slaxhd.gz**). * Make a floppy with **grldr** as boot loader, add **grub.exe** , add the files of your dos image and the compressed harddisk image (**slaxhd.gz**) of the previous step to it. * Make a **menu.lst** on the floppy: ``` timeout 0 title Boot Slax from SD map --mem (fd0)/slaxhd.gz (hd0) map --hook root (fd0) kernel /io.sys ``` It will first make a virtual hd drive, to which you can write later. Then it will boot msdos. * Add code in your **autoexec.bat** that copies the **/boot** folder of slax from the SD card to the memory mapped hard disk image. * After that, add the following in **autoexec.bat** : ``` grub.exe --config-file="root (hd0); chainloader +1" ``` This will boot the syslinux bootloader from the virtual hard drive. The contents of the virtual hard drive are copied each time from the SD card before booting, so if you edit **syslinux.cfg** on the SD card, the menu on the virtual hard drive changes to. So you can update slax to a new version very easily (just update the file on the SD card). Maybe you can make the virtual hard disk image bigger than 8MB to be sure that you don't need to make it again because the /boot folder did grow in size.

Syslinux can in no way directly chainloaded by grub4dos, see [http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7013](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7013 "External link")  

Currently the only way to chainload syslinux from grub4dos is to write syslinux into a Volume Boot Record (use syslinux.exe d:, d: exchange with your letter) and to store that Volume Boot Record into a file (use hdhacker or similar tool). The file is not generic (each time you change partitions you need to create it again). But the file can be chainloaded by grub4dos with chainloader /syslinux.bin. Syslinux.bin will keep care to load ldlinux.sys then.  

> DOS (Floppy) - LinLd/GrUB4DOS - SysLinux (SD card)?

DOS (Floppy) -\> LinLd -\> SysLinux on USB cardreader: This can not work. LinLD can afaik only boot files in Linux kernel format. Syslinux is not in Linux kernel format and there is no Syslinux version in linux kernel format. EDIT: Even if syslinux would get somehow chainloaded from USB (supported by DOS USB driver) it would not work as syslinux is also using only the BIOS to access devices, DOS USB drivers are ignored.  

DOS (Floppy) + DOS USB drivers -\> GrUB4DOS -\> SysLinux on USB cardreader: This can not work. grub4dos will freeze DOS (with option to unfreeze) and use only the BIOS (which has no USB support) in order to chainload other devices, therefore grub4dos is not aware of the USB cardreader.  

If the USB cardreader is not seen by PLoP Bootmanager (this is the case here) you can only do it like:  
BIOS -\> floppy with DOS and DOS USB driver -\> LinLD -\> Linux kernel.

You can make a image file (**slax.img** ) which contains the kernel and initrd of slax and syslinux in the bootsector (+ needed menu files for syslinux) + menu.lst file + the squash file of slax.  

Make a kexec-loader config that boots grub4dos (you need grub.exe)

kernel (sdb1)/grub.exe

initrd (sdb1)/slax.img

ramdisk image from which it can read the menu.lst file, the kernel and initrd.

```
title slax

chainloader +1
```

@ Bicephale My approach described above with grub4dos should work. Probably it wasn't clear enough. * You have to make a disk image of 8 MB (slax.img) or larger (depends on the size of the /boot folder of slax). Make a hard disk image, install syslinux as bootloader on it. Copy the whole boot folder of slax to the hard disk image. * Put this hard disk image on your SD card (slax.img) * Put the /slax folder on your SD card. * Put grub.exe on your SD card. * Make the config file for kexec-loader: You can use the label name of your SD card to set the root device in kexec-loader (e.g. label 'SLAX'). ``` root LABEL=SLAX title Slax kernel /grub.exe --config-file="find --set-root /boot/slax.cfg; chainloader +1" initrd /slax.img ```
* This will first boot kexec-loader, which can see your SD card. * kexec-loader will find his config file on the SD card. * kexec-loader will then grab grub.exe and slax.img from the SD card. * kexec-loader will boot grub.exe with slax.img as ramdisk. * grub.exe will boot syslinux from the slax.img (which is in memory now, so grub.exe can access this image) by chainloading the first sector.
So you will still have the syslinux menu, from which you can choose the options that you like.

It will work exactly as on a USB thumb drive on a PC that supports USB booting. Can you try it, at least?
You can also use your dos image that you made. * Make a hard disk image of 8MB (size depends on the size of the /boot folder of slax) and format it with fat16. Install **syslinux** to it. * Compress this image with gzip so it will fit on a floppy (will be only a few kb in size now) (**slaxhd.gz**). * Make a floppy with **grldr** as boot loader, add **grub.exe** , add the files of your dos image and the compressed harddisk image (**slaxhd.gz**) of the previous step to it. * Make a **menu.lst** on the floppy: ``` timeout 0 title Boot Slax from SD map --mem (fd0)/slaxhd.gz (hd0) map --hook root (fd0) kernel /io.sys ``` It will first make a virtual hd drive, to which you can write later. Then it will boot msdos. * Add code in your **autoexec.bat** that copies the **/boot** folder of slax from the SD card to the memory mapped hard disk image. * After that, add the following in **autoexec.bat** : ``` grub.exe --config-file="root (hd0); chainloader +1" ``` This will boot the syslinux bootloader from the virtual hard drive. The contents of the virtual hard drive are copied each time from the SD card before booting, so if you edit **syslinux.cfg** on the SD card, the menu on the virtual hard drive changes to. So you can update slax to a new version very easily (just update the file on the SD card). Maybe you can make the virtual hard disk image bigger than 8MB to be sure that you don't need to make it again because the /boot folder did grow in size.
